title: How to Grow Sprouts Indoors

steps.headline: Choose your sprouts.
steps.description:
You can use broccoli, fenugreek, lentils, peas, alfalfa and radish, or a mixture of all 3. You can buy these at many food or garden stores, or you can order them online. Buy organic seeds if you can, to make sure they aren't treated with chemicals. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c8\/Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/c\/c8\/Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/aid1606892-v4-728px-Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

steps.headline: Sterilize mason jars.
steps.description:
Large, wide-mouthed canning mason jars are available at cooking supply stores and even some supermarkets. You can reuse jars that you have used in the past, but they should be carefully sterilized. Fill each mason jar 1/5 full of bleach and fill the remaining container with hot water. Let the jar sit for a minute, then rinse it thoroughly. Repeat with each jar you have. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/83\/Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/8\/83\/Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/aid1606892-v4-728px-Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Separate the cap of the canning jar lid from the ring.
steps.description: You will not need to use the lid.

steps.headline: Cut a circle of mesh screen the size of the canning lid.
steps.description: This will be placed on top of the mason jar, below the canning lid ring.

steps.headline: Sterilize the ring and the mesh by placing it in boiling water for 5 minutes.
Pour 1 to 4 tablespoon (59.1 ml).
steps.description: (10 to 40 g) of seeds into each sterilized jar.

steps.headline: Fill the mason jar halfway full with cool water.
Place the circle of mesh on top of the jar and screw the lid ring into place.
Swirl the seeds around and then pour the water out to rinse them.
Fill halfway full with cool water again.
Leave the jar for 8 hours to allow the seeds to be completely soaked.
Pour the water out through the mesh cover.
Prop the jar at a 45 degree angle in a bowl so that the seeds can continue to drain.
Rinse the seeds twice a day.
steps.description: Fill the mason jar, pouring it out and allow it to drain at a 45 degree angle, like you did the first time. They must be rinsed regularly to avoid mold growth.

steps.headline: Repeat for 3 to 6 days, until the sprouts are approximately 0.5 to 1.5 inches (1.3 to 3.8 cm) long.
Transfer to a covered container and store them in the refrigerator.

text:
Choose your sprouts. You can use broccoli, fenugreek, lentils, peas, alfalfa and radish, or a mixture of all 3. You can buy these at many food or garden stores, or you can order them online. Buy organic seeds if you can, to make sure they aren't treated with chemicals. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/c/c8/Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/aid1606892-v4-728px-Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Sterilize mason jars. Large, wide-mouthed canning mason jars are available at cooking supply stores and even some supermarkets. You can reuse jars that you have used in the past, but they should be carefully sterilized. Fill each mason jar 1/5 full of bleach and fill the remaining container with hot water. Let the jar sit for a minute, then rinse it thoroughly. Repeat with each jar you have. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/8/83/Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/aid1606892-v4-728px-Grow-Sprouts-Indoors-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Separate the cap of the canning jar lid from the ring. You will not need to use the lid. Cut a circle of mesh screen the size of the canning lid. This will be placed on top of the mason jar, below the canning lid ring. Sterilize the ring and the mesh by placing it in boiling water for 5 minutes. Pour 1 to 4 tablespoon (59.1 ml). (10 to 40 g) of seeds into each sterilized jar. Fill the mason jar halfway full with cool water. Place the circle of mesh on top of the jar and screw the lid ring into place. Swirl the seeds around and then pour the water out to rinse them. Fill halfway full with cool water again. Leave the jar for 8 hours to allow the seeds to be completely soaked. Pour the water out through the mesh cover. Prop the jar at a 45 degree angle in a bowl so that the seeds can continue to drain. Rinse the seeds twice a day. Fill the mason jar, pouring it out and allow it to drain at a 45 degree angle, like you did the first time. They must be rinsed regularly to avoid mold growth. Repeat for 3 to 6 days, until the sprouts are approximately 0.5 to 1.5 inches (1.3 to 3.8 cm) long. Transfer to a covered container and store them in the refrigerator.
